Involving civil society organizations and media in monitoring procurement processes can act as a check on the government's actions and increase transparency in procurement processes. Civil society organizations can act as watchdogs and help to detect any irregularities that might be missed by government oversight bodies. By monitoring the procurement process, documenting any irregularities, and advocating for transparency and accountability, civil society organizations can help to create pressure for reform and better government practices. The media also plays a crucial role in exposing corruption and illuminating procurement processes, which can help to build public trust and confidence in the government. Therefore, involving civil society organizations and media in monitoring procurement processes can serve as a powerful tool to increase transparency and accountability and help to prevent corruption.
